headline.main: The Gaps in Mental Health Care and Coverage

docs.abstract: Bucks readers share stories about their efforts to get health insurers or their employers to cover treatment for mental illnesses and autism.
docs.snippet: Bucks readers share stories about their efforts to get health insurers or their employers to cover treatment for mental illnesses and autism.

headline.main: Apollo Unit to Buy Aviva's U.S. Unit for $1.8 Billion

docs.abstract: A unit of Apollo Global Management agreed on Friday to buy the American operations of Aviva, the British insurer, for about $1.55 billion in cash.
docs.snippet: A unit of Apollo Global Management agreed on Friday to buy the American operations of Aviva, the British insurer, for about $1.55 billion in cash.

byline.original: By MICHAEL J. DE LA MERCED

headline.main: Medicare Spending Isn't Out of Control

docs.abstract: Compared with spending by private health insurers, Medicare looks efficient and prudent, an economist writes.
docs.snippet: Compared with spending by private health insurers, Medicare looks efficient and prudent, an economist writes.

docs.lead_paragraph: A former medical editor discusses the costs, including societal costs, of not doing so.
docs.snippet: A former medical editor discusses the costs, including societal costs, of not doing so.

docs.lead_paragraph: Those registered for the 2012 New York City Marathon, canceled after Hurricane Sandy, were offered a full refund or entry into a race from 2013 to 2015 at this year’s rates.

headline.seo: New York City Marathon Organizers Announce Restitution Plan
headline.main: Marathon Organizers Offer Refund or Future Race
headline.print_headline: Marathon Organizers Offer Refund or Future Race

docs.abstract: New York Road Runners Club announces that runners who registered for the 2012 New York City Marathon, which was canceled because of Hurricane Sandy, can get either a full refund or entry into a race from 2013 to 2015 at 2012 rates.
docs.snippet: Those registered for the 2012 New York City Marathon, canceled after Hurricane Sandy, were offered a full refund or entry into a race from 2013 to 2015 at this year’s rates.

byline.original: By KEN BELSON and MARY PILON

headline.main: Where Have All the Primary Care Doctors Gone?

docs.abstract: The one in five young doctors who still planned on a career in general medicine at the completion of their training may help to provide the answer to the current primary care shortage, a new study found.
docs.snippet: The one in five young doctors who still planned on a career in general medicine at the completion of their training may help to provide the answer to the current primary care shortage, a new study found.

docs.lead_paragraph: A Manhattan family was already struggling with financial problems when the unthinkable happened: their 17-year-old son was shot to death.

headline.seo: After a Son’s Death, a Family Struggles to Move On
headline.main: Struggling to Go On After a Son’s Death
headline.print_headline: Struggling to Go On After a Son’s Death

docs.abstract: Children's Aid Society helps Kendrick Moore and Carol Bowman-Moore, whose 17-year-old son was fatally shot on Staten Island during a robbery, get support they need to feed their family and pay their bills.
docs.snippet: A Manhattan family was already struggling with financial problems when the unthinkable happened: their 17-year-old son was shot to death.

keywords.value: New York Times Neediest Cases Fund
keywords.name: organizations

docs.lead_paragraph: The Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act appears here to stay, but many of those it is supposed to help still do not understand what the law can do for them, officials have found.

headline.seo: Officials Confront Skepticism Over Health Law
headline.main: Next Challenge for the Health Law: Getting the Public to Buy In
headline.print_headline: Next Challenge for the Health Law: Getting the Public to Buy In

docs.abstract: Nonprofit group Enroll America is preparing to roll out program to educate uninsured Americans about benefits provided under the Affordable Care Act; officials have found that many uninsured have a poor understanding of the law, and are unlikely to take advantage of online markets when it goes into effect.
docs.snippet: The Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act appears here to stay, but many of those it is supposed to help still do not understand what the law can do for them, officials have found.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Despite the dueling news conferences and stream of well-rehearsed sound bites from the White House and Congress about the budget talks, one element is still largely missing from the debate: details about spending cuts.

headline.main: Both Sides Stand Firm on Details: You First

docs.abstract: Despite the dueling news conferences and stream of well-rehearsed sound bites from the White House and Congress about the budget talks, one element is still largely missing from the debate: details about spending cuts.
docs.snippet: Despite the dueling news conferences and stream of well-rehearsed sound bites from the White House and Congress about the budget talks, one element is still largely missing from the debate: details about spending cuts.

headline.main: A Tale of Two Welfare States

docs.abstract: Britain’s determination to unify its antipoverty programs and the United States’ creation of more programs will offer a sharp contrast in policymaking.
docs.snippet: Britain’s determination to unify its antipoverty programs and the United States’ creation of more programs will offer a sharp contrast in policymaking.
